source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk1
evidence_span: Zircaloy-4 (nominal composition: $Z \mathrm { r } { - } 1 . 5 \mathrm { S n } { - 0 . 2 \mathrm { F e - } 0 . 1 \mathrm { C r } }

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk1
evidence_span: the corrosion resistance of zirconium-base alloys compared with that of Zircaloy-4 ... was significantly improved by the reduction of the Sn content by $0 . 5 ~ \mathrm { w t } \%$ and by a small addition of Nb (about 0.05 to $0 . 2 \ \mathrm { w t } \%$ )
composition_raw: Sn reduction by 0.5 wt%; Nb: 0.05-0.2 wt%

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk1
evidence_span: the decrease in solute Sn atoms degraded mechanical properties such as ultimate tensile strength and $0 . 2 \%$ yield strength

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk1
evidence_span: The increase of the total content of Fe and Cr from 0.3 to $0 . 7 \mathrm { w t } \%$ improved the mechanical properties without affecting the corrosion resistance

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk1
evidence_span: Small additions of Mo and/or $\mathrm { V }$ resulted in a further improvement of mechanical properties

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk1
evidence_span: The corrosion resistance increased and the average size of precipitates decreased from 0.1 to $0 . 0 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ with the decrease of the $\mathrm { F e / C r }$ ratio from 6.0 to 0.5

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk2
evidence_span: further additions of more than about $0 . 2 \%$ lead to an increase in weight gain.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk2
evidence_span: With decreasing Sn content, weight gains generally decreased (i.e.. corrosion resistances increased).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk2
evidence_span: Thus the corrosion resistance of zirconium-base alloys, especially Zircaloy-4. could be significantly improved by the reduction of the Sn content to $0 . 5 \%$ and a small addition of $\mathbf { N b }$ (about 0.05 to $0 . 2 \%$ ).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk2
evidence_span: FIG. 4—Tensile strength as a function of Sn conient at room temperature.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk2
evidence_span: FIG. 5—Tensile strength as a function of Nb content at room temperature.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk2
evidence_span: Ultimate tensile strength (U.T.S.) and $0 . 2 \%$ yield strength $( 0 . 2 \%$ Y.S.) decreased with decreasing Sn content.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk2
evidence_span: Ultimate tensile strength (U.T.S.) and $0 . 2 \%$ yield strength $( 0 . 2 \%$ Y.S.) decreased with decreasing Sn content.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk2
evidence_span: The tensile strength increased with increasing Nb content up to $0 . 5 \%$ . but remains almost with further additions of Nb.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk2
evidence_span: the increase in strength by the addition of $\mathsf { N b }$ was not enough to compensate for the decrease in strength due to the reduction in Sn content.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk3
evidence_span: The average size of precipitate of the small $\mathrm { F e / C r }$ ratio (0.5) alloy is smaller than that of the large ratio (6.0) alloy.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk3
evidence_span: The average size of precipitate of the small $\mathrm { F e / C r }$ ratio (0.5) alloy is smaller than that of the large ratio (6.0) alloy.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk3
evidence_span: the corrosion resistance of niobium-containing zirconium-base aloys tended to decrease with increasing $\mathbf { F e / C r }$ ratio.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk3
evidence_span: the content of alloying elements dissolved in the matrix of low Fe/Cr ratio alloy is much higher than that of the high $\mathbf { F e / C r }$ ratio alloy. This is the reason for the high strength of the former material.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk3
evidence_span: The addition of Mo and $\mathbf { V }$ increases the weight gains (i.e., these elements lower corrosion resistance).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk3
evidence_span: The addition of Mo and $\mathbf { V }$ increases the weight gains (i.e., these elements lower corrosion resistance).

evidence_span: Tensile strengths increase with increasing content of Mo

evidence_span: Corrosion tests were performed in $6 \bar { 3 } 3 ~ \mathrm { K }$ water and $6 7 3 \mathrm { ~ K ~ }$ steam for a total of $7 2 0 0 \ \mathrm { h }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk5
evidence_span: Corrosion tests were performed in $6 \bar { 3 } 3 ~ \mathrm { K }$ water

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk5
evidence_span: Corrosion tests were performed in $6 7 3 \mathrm { ~ K ~ }$ steam

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk5
evidence_span: Zircaloy-type alloys showed typical corrosion behavior with a rate transition

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk5
evidence_span: In the pretransition region almost all alloys showed the same behavior

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk5
evidence_span: the post-transition corrosion rate increased with tin content

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk5
evidence_span: Iron increased the post-transition corrosion rate in $6 7 3 \mathrm { ~ K ~ }$ steam

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk5
evidence_span: the effect of chromium was negligible

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk5
evidence_span: A small addition of nickel was effective in reducing post-transition corrosion rate, but larger amounts did not markedly improve the resistance
value: reduced with small addition, no marked improvement with larger amounts

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk5
evidence_span: The effect of impurities was also negligibly small within the variation of the contents in this study
composition_raw: impurities (oxygen, carbon, nitrogen, silicon, aluminum, phosphorus)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk5
evidence_span: The effects of alloying elements in the binary alloys were basically the same as that in Zircaloys
value: basically the same as in Zircaloys

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk5
evidence_span: niobium and tantalum had a remarkable effect in improving the corrosion resistance

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk5
evidence_span: The effects of tin, iron, and chromium on hydrogen pick-up fraction were small

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk5
evidence_span: nickel, however, had a significant effect

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk5
evidence_span: The composition of second-phase particles in Zircaloys varied with the contents of alloying elements
